change.changenote: Regulation BEFORE repealed by BC Reg 270/2008, effective October 17, 2008.

reg.title: Traditional Chinese Medicine Practitioners and Acupuncturists Regulation

definition.def: means a disease, disorder or dysfunction which has disabling or life-threatening effects and which will not improve without immediate or surgical intervention;

means an act of stimulation, by means of needles, of specific sites on the skin, mucous membranes or subcutaneous tissues of the human body to promote, maintain, restore or improve health, to prevent a disorder, imbalance or disease or to alleviate pain and includes

paragraph.paragraphtext: the administration of manual, mechanical, thermal and electrical stimulation of acupuncture needles,
the use of laser acupuncture, magnetic therapy or acupressure, and

definition.def: means a registrant authorized under the bylaws to practise acupuncture;
means a person authorized under the Dentists Act to practise dentistry;
means a traditional Chinese medicine practitioner who is authorized under the bylaws to use the title "doctor of traditional Chinese medicine";
means a registrant authorized under the bylaws to prescribe, compound or dispense Chinese herbal formulae (Zhong Yao Chu Fang) and Chinese food cure recipes (Shi Liao);
means a person authorized under the Medical Practitioners Act to practise medicine;
means a person authorized under the Naturopathic Physicians Regulation to practise naturopathic medicine;
means to give directions, either orally or in writing, for the preparation and administration of a traditional Chinese medicine remedy to be used in the treatment of a disorder or an imbalance;
means the promotion, maintenance and restoration of health and prevention of a disorder, imbalance or disease based on traditional Chinese medicine theory by utilization of the primary therapies of

paragraph.paragraphtext: Chinese acupuncture (Zhen), moxibustion (Jiu) and suction cup (Ba Guan),
Chinese rehabilitation exercises such as Chinese shadow boxing (Tai Ji Quan), and
prescribing, compounding or dispensing Chinese herbal formulae (Zhong Yao Chu Fang) and Chinese food cure recipes (Shi Liao);

definition.def: means a registrant authorized under the bylaws to practise traditional Chinese medicine.

subsection.subsectiontext: Traditional Chinese medicine and acupuncture are designated as health professions.
The "College of Traditional Chinese Medicine Practitioners and Acupuncturists of British Columbia" is the name of the college established to regulate traditional Chinese medicine and acupuncture.
No person other than an acupuncturist may use the title "acupuncturist".
No person other than a traditional Chinese medicine practitioner may use the title "traditional Chinese medicine practitioner".
No person other than a herbalist may use the title "traditional Chinese medicine herbalist".
No person other than a doctor of traditional Chinese medicine may use the title "doctor of traditional Chinese medicine".
An acupuncturist may practise acupuncture, including

paragraph.paragraphtext: the use of traditional Chinese medicine diagnostic techniques, and
the recommendation of dietary guidelines or therapeutic exercise.

subsection.subsectiontext: A traditional Chinese medicine practitioner may practise traditional Chinese medicine.

section.sectiontext: Subject to section 14 of the Act,

paragraph.paragraphtext: only a traditional Chinese medicine practitioner, acupuncturist or herbalist may make a traditional Chinese medicine diagnosis identifying a disease, disorder or condition as the cause of signs or symptoms,
only a traditional Chinese medicine practitioner or a herbalist may prescribe those Chinese herbal formulae listed in a schedule to the bylaws of the College, and
only a traditional Chinese medicine practitioner or an acupuncturist may insert acupuncture needles under the skin for the purposes of practising acupuncture.

subsection.subsectiontext: No acupuncturist or herbalist may treat an active serious medical condition unless the client has consulted with a medical practitioner, naturopath, dentist or doctor of traditional Chinese medicine, as appropriate.

A traditional Chinese medicine practitioner or an acupuncturist may only administer acupuncture as a surgical anaesthetic if a medical practitioner or a dentist is physically present and observing the procedure.

An acupuncturist or herbalist must advise the client to consult a medical practitioner, naturopath, dentist or doctor of traditional Chinese medicine if there is no improvement in the condition for which the client is being treated within two months of receiving treatment.
In the event a client does not consult with a medical practitioner, naturopath, dentist or doctor of traditional Chinese medicine, an acupuncturist or herbalist must discontinue treatment if

paragraph.paragraphtext: there is no improvement in the condition for which the client is being treated after four months from the date treatment commenced,
the condition for which the client is being treated worsens, or

subsection.subsectiontext: An acupuncturist or herbalist must not use traditional Chinese medicine diagnostic techniques except as authorized in the bylaws.

section.sectiontext: The college is designated for the purposes of section 16 (2) (f) of the Act.

content.regnote: Note: this regulation replaces B.C. Reg. 80/96.
